title: Fears 120,000,000 rats could invade our homes in the cold weather
text:
Rats that are ‘hungry and cold’ could try to get into homes (Picture: Getty)

Rats that are ‘hungry and cold’ could start invading homes across the UK in search for somewhere warmer, pest control chiefs warn.

Britain is said to be home to some 120 million brown rats – nearly double the human population – that have been blamed for causing thousands of pounds worth of damage.

The rats can have up to six litters of up to 12 babies each year and have been known to break into loft and attic spaces to escape the cold winter weather.

Experts blame the rodents for fires caused by gnawing through electrical cables as well as structural damage to homes by rats eating away at beams.

Paul Bates, the boss of Cleankill Pest Control, is warning people to ‘act now’ to prepare homes against an invasion of the creatures.

He said pest control companies can see a 30 to 40 per cent rise in call-outs for rodent infestations at this time of year.

Paul urged people that hear ‘scuttling and scratching sounds’ around their homes to get it investigated.

He said: ‘Recent heavy rain has forced many rats above ground.

Rats often make nests in loft spaces by crawling through gaps in doors and brickwork (Picture: Getty)

‘There is lots of food around for rats at the moment, with ripe fruit and crops from harvesting, so the rat population is peaking at the moment.

‘As it gets colder, however, as it is now, rats will move closer to food supplies indoors and for somewhere warm to nest – that means people’s homes.’

Paul believes the rat population is ‘peaking’ at this time of year because of late-season fruit ripening, like plums, apples and blackberries.

But in the weeks to come, those rats will take ‘refuge’ indoors as food supplies dwindle.

David Penman, 39, of Hastings, East Sussex, said he moved home because of a rat infestation.

The architectural assistant said: ‘I was living in a two-bed rented flat and the noise from the rats last winter was dreadful.

‘I couldn’t get a wink of sleep some nights and ended up staying at a friend’s house over the weekend just to get some proper sleep. I even booked a hotel for two nights just to get away from the noise.

‘In the end I moved house as the landlord was doing nothing about the rats.’

How to make your home rat-proof STEP 1 – Check brickwork to ensure air bricks – which allow ventilation – are intact as larger Victorian ones have gaps large enough for rodents to sneak through

STEP 2 – Remove kick plates from the bottom of kitchen units and clear out any food debris and check for rat droppings

STEP 3 – Clear out stair cupboards and check pipework for holes where rodents can sneak in and make a winter nest

STEP 4 – Check your loft or attack for signs of ‘invasion’

STEP 5 – Remove garden rubbish and debris which attracts rats and keep a tidy garden

STEP 6 – Don’t feed birds by scattering food in your garden as this attracts rats, use specialist bird feeders

STEP 7 – Put brush strips on your doors to stop rats getting in

Paul said there were several steps to take to try and stop the rodents sneaking into your home, including blocking any gaps in brickwork and clearing out stair cupboards, as well as putting all food away in cupboards.

He said: ‘It’s so much better to take preventive action now. It’s amazing how often we find external doors that simply don’t fit properly.

‘A rat can get through tiny gaps – and mice can get though a gap as wide as a pencil – so if there is a gap, make sure you fit a bristle-strip draft excluder to the base.’

But he warned ‘no house is completely rodent proof’.
